title: 109_hr6129
content: The Act titled "Credit Monitoring Clarification Act" clarifies credit monitoring services. The Credit Repair Organizations Act is amended to clarify that certain credit monitoring services are not considered as activities under the Act. The Credit Repair Organizations Act is amended to exclude certain credit monitoring services from its regulations, including providing consumer credit score projections, assisting identity theft victims, and offering explanations of credit scores under different scenarios. The Credit Repair Organizations Act is amended to exclude credit repair companies from claiming they can modify accurate credit information or alter consumer identification to hide negative information. The Credit Repair Organizations Act prohibits credit repair companies from falsely claiming they can modify or remove accurate credit information from a consumer's credit report. The Credit Repair Organizations Act allows consumers to dispute inaccurate information in their credit report by contacting the credit bureau directly. Consumers have the right to obtain a free copy of their credit report once every 12 months from each nationwide consumer reporting agency. To request your free annual credit report, visit www.annualcreditreport.com, call 877-322-8228, or mail the Annual Credit Report Request Form to: Annual Credit Report Request Service, P.O. Box 105281, Atlanta, GA 30348-5281. Additional copies can be obtained from a credit bureau for a fee, except if you've been denied credit, employment, insurance, or housing due to your credit report within the last 60 days. In such cases, a free copy must be provided with assistance in interpreting the information. You have the right to receive a free credit report if you are unemployed, receive public welfare assistance, or suspect fraud. You can cancel a credit monitoring service at any time without penalty and may receive a refund for prepaid months. The Federal Trade Commission oversees credit bureaus and monitoring services. Contact them for more information. The Federal Trade Commission in Washington, D.C. can be contacted at 1-877-FTC-HELP or www.ftc.gov. If the contract is for a credit monitoring service, consumers can cancel without fee or penalty at any time. If billed for credit monitoring on a non-monthly basis, consumers will receive a pro rata refund if they cancel within 30 days of the telephone. Consumers can cancel a credit monitoring service at any time without penalty. If billed on a non-monthly basis, they will receive a pro rata refund if canceled within 30 days of initial communication. The Credit Repair Organizations Act allows consumers to cancel services without penalty and receive a pro rata refund if canceled within 30 days. Refunds must be issued within 60 days of cancellation notice. Clarifications are made regarding nonexempt status and disclosure requirements. The Credit Repair Organizations Act now includes a revised disclosure requirement stating that individuals can dispute inaccurate credit report information directly with the credit bureau. Credit repair companies cannot remove accurate information, and negative information can only be removed after 7 years. Bankruptcy information can be reported for 10 years. Consumers have the right to request a free copy of their credit report annually from each nationwide consumer reporting agency. To request your free annual credit report, visit www.annualcreditreport.com, call 877-322-8228, or mail the Annual Credit Report Request Form to: Annual Credit Report Request Service, P.O. Box 105281, Atlanta, GA 30348-5281. Additional copies can be obtained from a credit bureau for a fee. No fee is charged if you were denied credit, employment, insurance, or housing due to your credit report within the last 60 days. You can also get a free report if you are unemployed and plan to apply for a job soon, receive public welfare assistance, or suspect fraud in your report. If you suspect inaccurate information in your credit report due to fraud, you have the right to dispute it with the credit bureau. They must investigate and correct any errors without charging a fee. Additionally, you can sue a credit repair organization that violates the Credit Repair Organizations Act, which prohibits deceptive practices. You also have the right to cancel your contract with a credit repair organization within 3 business days of signing it. If the credit bureau's reinvestigation does not resolve the dispute to your satisfaction, you may send a brief statement explaining why you think the record is inaccurate. The Federal Trade Commission regulates credit bureaus and credit repair organizations. Contact the Federal Trade Commission for more information. Effective Date: Section 403(b)(2)(E) of the Credit Repair Organizations Act shall take effect upon the enactment of this Act. The Credit Repair Organizations Act requires written disclosures to be updated if changes are made to centralized source contact information for obtaining a free credit report after enactment of the Act.
